Fig. 1 Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of proton-form (A) Al-MCM-22, (B) Ga-MCM-22, (C) Al-SSZ-13, (D) Ga-SSZ-13, (E) Al-ZSM-5, and (F) Ga-ZSM-5. Fig. 2 XPS spectra of Ga 2p for (A) Ga-MCM-22, (B) Ga-SSZ-13, and (C) Ga-ZSM-5 proton-form samples. Spectra have been corrected using carbon peaks as a reference. Peak deconvolution was performed using Gaussian fits to extract relative contributions of framework (green) and extra-framework (purple) gallium species from the sum of both contributions (red). See Fig. S6 for corresponding XPS Si 2p spectra. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 3 (A) Solid-state MAS 71Ga NMR spectra of Ga-ZSM-5 (top), Ga-SSZ-13 (middle), and Ga-MCM-22 (bottom) proton-form samples. (B – G) Potential framework and extra-framework Ga species that have been reported for Ga-zeolites [26,44]. Fig. 4 Comparison of Ga-zeolites for methanol dehydration at 350 °C and a weight-hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 8 h−1. (A) Conversion of methanol over proton-form Ga-MCM-22 (squares), Ga-SSZ-13 (triangles), and Ga-ZSM-5 (diamonds) catalysts as a function of time on stream (TOS). (B) Corresponding product selectivity of each Ga-zeolite. A full comparison of product selectivity as a function of TOS and turnover frequency are provided in Figs. S7 and S8 of the Supplementary Information, respectively. Solid lines are interpolated to guide the eye. Fig. 5 Comparison of methanol dehydration catalysts reported in literature with Ga-MCM-22 (gold star) in this study. Details of each catalyst and corresponding reaction conditions are provided in Table S3 of the Supplementary Information. Data were obtained from the review of Bateni and Able [7] with the omission of several classes of methanol dehydration catalysts that are outside the compositional space of materials examined in this study (e.g., heteropoly acids, metal oxides, ion-exchange resins, and quasicrystals). Fig. 6 (A) Methanol/DME conversion during the methanol-to-hydrocarbons reaction over dual catalyst beds (B1 and B2 in Scheme 1) with the following combinations: (i) B1 = Ga-MCM-22 and B2 = Al-ZSM-5 (blue triangles); (ii) B1 = Ga-SSZ-13 and B2 = Al-ZSM-5 (red squares); and (iii) B1 = Ga-ZSM-5 and B2 = Al-ZSM-5 (orange hexagons). Reactions were carried out at 350 ℃ with WHSV = 7 and 3 h−1 for upstream and downstream beds, respectively. Comparisons were made to single catalyst beds containing Al-ZSM-5 (control, black circles) and a physical mixture of Ga-MCM-22 and Al-ZSM-5 (purple diamonds). Solid lines are interpolated to guide the eye. (B) Corresponding product selectivities evaluated at the initial time on stream (ca. 30 min) for both dual and single beds. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 7 Comparison of Ga-zeolites for ethanol dehydration at 500 °C and WHSV = 19 h−1. (A) Conversion of ethanol over proton-forms of Ga-MCM-22 (squares), Ga-SSZ-13 (triangles), and Ga-ZSM-5 (diamonds) as a function of time on stream (TOS). (B) Corresponding ethylene selectivity of each Ga-zeolite. A full comparison of product selectivity as a function of TOS is provided in Fig. S11 of the Supplementary Information. Solid lines are interpolated to guide the eye. Fig. 8 Production of propylene from ethanol at 500 ℃ and WHSV = 5 and 3 h−1 for upstream and downstream beds, respectively. Four bed configurations were tested: (A) single bed of Al-SSZ-13 (WHSV = 3 h−1), (B) a dual bed with tandem catalysts Ga-MCM-22 (B1) and Al-SSZ-13 (B2), (C) a dual bed with Ga-SSZ-13 (B1) and Al-SSZ-13 (B2), and (D) a dual bed with Ga-ZSM-5 (B1) and Al-SSZ-13 (B2). For each set of data, the conversion (black symbols) is the left y-axis and the selectivity (orange, blue, green, and red symbols) is the right y-axis. Solid lines are interpolated to guide the eye. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Brookshire Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering University of Houston 4226 Martin Luther King Boulevard Houston TX 77204 USA Graphical abstract This study examines Ga-zeolites as heterogeneous catalysts for alcohol dehydration and as critical components of tandem catalysts in dual bed configurations where Al-zeolites placed downstream selectively convert intermediates to light olefins. Zeolites are versatile catalysts owing to their tunable acidity where the active site(s) can be placed within the crystal framework or as extra-framework species in confined pores. A common approach to tailor Brønsted acidity is heteroatom exchange involving the replacement of framework aluminum with alternative elements. Introduction of heteroatoms often results in less acidic catalysts that can be used in tandem reactions for targeted reactive intermediates. In this study, we prepare a series of three different zeolites with MWW, CHA, and MFI frameworks as aluminosilicates and gallosilicates to demonstrate their performance in alcohol dehydration reactions. The two reactions examined in this study are methanol conversion to dimethyl ether and ethanol conversion to ethylene. Our findings reveal that Ga-zeolites exhibit superior performance with Ga-MCM-22 (MWW) achieving nearly 100 % alcohol conversion and selectivity to desired products at contact times that are significantly less than most dehydration catalysts reported in literature. The unique properties of Ga-zeolites are attributed to their reduced acid site strength via a direct (one-pot) synthesis that avoids conventional time-intensive, multi-step post-synthesis modifications of Al-zeolites. Here we demonstrate the use of Ga-zeolites as tandem catalysts when paired with a downstream Al-zeolite in a dual-bed reactor configuration to convert cheaper reagents (alcohols) upstream to more desired intermediates as feeds for downstream catalysts to produce light olefins. We demonstrate that dual beds using Ga-zeolite – Al-ZSM-5 (upstream–downstream) pairings outperform single bed configurations with Al-ZSM-5 or a physical mixture (Ga-/Al-zeolite) for methanol to hydrocarbons reactions, with notable improvements in catalyst lifetime and increased light olefins selectivity. Similarly, dual beds using Ga-zeolite – Al-SSZ-13 (upstream–downstream) pairings result in improved performance for ethanol to propylene reactions with significant increases in propylene selectivity (>20 %) compared to a conventional single bed configuration of Al-SSZ-13. Overall, this study offers a new perspective on the use of heteroatom-exchanged zeolite catalysts in tandem reactions as a means of capitalizing on their reduced acid site strength and suggests differences in the intrinsic acidity of zeolite crystal structures. Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Light olefins are heavily utilized in commercial processes as fundamental building blocks for a myriad of materials that include plastics, synthetic fibers, packaging materials, and automotive parts [1–3]. The market demand for light olefins, notably ethylene and propylene, is expected to grow from 109 million tons in 2014 to around 165 million tons by 2030 [4]. The most common route of light olefin production is the thermal cracking of naphtha, which is considered the single-most energy consuming process in the chemical industry [5]. Less energy intensive routes of olefin production include reactions such as methanol to olefins (MTO), alkane dehydrogenation, synthesis gas to olefins, and alcohol dehydration, which are typically driven by aluminum-based zeolite/zeotype catalysts (e.g., ZSM-5, SAPO-34) owing to their desirable shape selectivity and acidity [4]. In particular, dehydration reactions are an efficient pathway to olefin production as they are derived from cheap, readily-available alcohol feedstocks [6]. A common characteristic of dehydration reactions is low operating temperatures (<250 °C), whereas further conversion of products to a variety of value-added chemicals often requires higher reaction temperatures [7,8]. The strong acidity of conventional Al-zeolites reduces the selectivity of alcohol dehydration reactions at higher temperature (≥300 °C), but enables subsequent transformations of dehydrated products to hydrocarbons [9,10]. There has been increased interest in the synthesis of zeolites with heteroatoms as alternatives to conventional Al-zeolites owing to their promise for enhanced catalytic performance [11–17]. Heteroatoms such as main group metals (Ge, Ga, Sn), non-metals (C, F, B), and transition metals (Cu, Zr, Fe, Ti) have been successfully introduced into zeolite frameworks in the form of TO4 tetrahedrons [12,18–21]. Replacement of Al with alternative heteroatoms has the potential to improve catalyst performance via the modulation of zeolite micropore structure, acidity, or particle size [22–26]. There are several methods of preparing heteroatom incorporated zeolites with distinct properties, which include (but are not limited to) direct hydrothermal synthesis, post-synthesis ion exchange, or wetness impregnation. Direct (or one-pot) syntheses are versatile approaches wherein heteroatom precursors (in the form of metal salts or metal organics) are introduced into growth mixtures and are hydrolyzed and reacted concurrently with a silicon source. One of the most commercially relevant heteroatom zeolites is Ti-silicalite-1 (TS-1, MFI type), which has been used for the epoxidation of olefins and alkanes since its discovery in the 1980s [22]. Mintova and coworkers [23] recently reported the incorporation of tungsten (W) in ZSM-5 (MFI type) as a method to reduce defects (silanols) and improve overall catalytic performance for the epoxidation of styrene. Another example includes the work of Hodoshima et al. who synthesized Fe- and Ga-substituted Al-ZSM-5 zeolites via a one-pot method for n-hexane cracking [24]. The incorporation of Fe led to a reduction in zeolite acid site strength while Ga improved the dehydrogenation activity for paraffinic hydrocarbons. Lercher and coworkers [25] reported a post-synthetic method to prepare Ga-beta zeolites (*BEA type) for propane dehydrogenation, whereas we previously reported a one-pot synthesis of bifunctional Ga,Al-ZSM-5 catalysts and demonstrated their exceptional performance in ethylene dehydroaromatization compared to analogues prepared by post-synthesis Ga exchange [26]. To our knowledge, we have not observed Ga-zeolites being used as alcohol dehydration catalysts at industrially relevant temperatures (350 °C for methanol to dimethyl ether (DME) and 500 °C for ethanol to ethylene reactions). Partial substitution of Al with heteroatoms and/or the introduction of extra-framework species to create multifunctional zeolites for tandem reactions is a topic that has gained significant attention for a broad class of catalysts in recent years [27–29]. Tandem reactions with multifunctional catalysts enable complex chemical transformations to be carried out in fewer steps for improved efficiency, economics, and sustainability [30–32]. Zhang and Wang [30] recently reported the highly-selective conversion of syngas to ethanol by a triple fixed reactor bed configuration using a series of catalysts where the first bed (K+-ZnO-ZrO2) converts syngas to methanol, the second bed (zeolite mordenite, MOR) performs methanol carbonylation to acetic acid, and the third bed (Pt-Sn/SiC) carries out hydrogenation to ethanol with ca. 90 % selectivity. Alternative configurations for tandem reactions of syngas to ethanol include a dual bed design by Lu and coworkers [31] who used metal impregnated Cu-MOR zeolite upstream for DME carbonylation to methyl acetate and a ternary oxide CuO/ZnO/Al2O3 (CZA) downstream for hydrogenation to ethanol. More specific to light olefin catalysis, Sasmaz and coworkers [32] recently demonstrated direct CO2 hydrogenation to light olefins over a dual bed reactor configuration where the upstream catalyst (In2O3/yttria-stabilized zirconia, YSZ) transforms CO2 to methanol and the downstream catalyst (zeotype SAPO-34) converts methanol into light olefins. These are only a few examples from published literature where the use of sequential reactor beds with multifunctional catalysts have demonstrated improved efficiency while simultaneously reducing waste and minimizing energy costs. Previous studies have shown that the substitution of Al in zeolite frameworks with other heteroatoms can signficantly change catalyst acid site strength leading to shifts in reaction rates. Accurate measurements of acid site strength in heterogeneous catalysts is nontrivial, as highlighted by Gorte and Crossley [33] who cautioned overinterpretation of NH3 temperature programmed desorption (TPD) measurements in favor of more rigorous deprotonation energy (DPE) measurements to quantify Brønsted acidity. Several previously reported studies, including those by Gorte, have assessed changes in Brønsted acid strength for heteroatom incorporated ZSM-5 using a combination of DPE, density functional theory (DFT), and Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR). [8,34–36]The collective measurements of these studies revealed an increasing acid strength of framework -Si(OH)T3+- groups (T = heteroatom tetrahedral site) in the following order: Si(OH)B < Si(OH)Fe < Si(OH)Ga < Si(OH)Al. In this study, we capitalize on the ability to tune the acid site strength of heteroatom-substituted zeolites in a dual-bed reactor configuration (Scheme 1 ) where a less acidic Ga-zeolite is used in the upstream bed to convert alcohols to desirable intermediates prior to their conversion to olefins in a downstream bed containing a more acidic Al-zeolite. We posit the selective formation of reactive intermediates from alcohol feeds over upstream Ga-zeolite catalysts will improve the performance of downstream Al-zeolite catalysts in terms of lifetime and/or olefin selectivity. Here, we report one-pot syntheses of three gallosilicates (Ga-zeolites) with MCM-22 (MWW), SSZ-13 (CHA), and ZSM-5 (MFI) structures. Small and medium pore zeolite frameworks (CHA and MFI, respectively) were selected to represent commercially available catalysts commonly used in MTO and MTH reactions while zeolite framework (MWW) was selected as an alternative medium-pore zeolite with a pore network distinct from MFI to assess the role of internal pore topology on catalyst performance. Our findings reveal that Ga-zeolites are both active and selective alcohol dehydration catalysts, which are paired with commercially-relevant Al-zeolites (ZSM-5 and SSZ-13) in two different tandem configurations to upgrade the products of methanol and ethanol dehydration, respectively. 2 Experimental methods 2.1 Materials The following chemicals were purchased from Sigma Aldrich: Sodium aluminate (NaAlO2, technical grade), gallium nitrate (Ga(NO3)3, 99.9 %), gallium oxide (Ga2O3, 99 %), hexamethylenimine (HMI, 99 %), sodium hydroxide (NaOH, 50 wt%), sodium hydroxide (NaOH, 1 M), ammonium nitrate (NH4NO3, 99.5 %), fumed silica (Cab-o-Sil, M−5, scintillation grade), and tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS, 98 %). Tetrapropylammonium hydroxide (TPAOH, 40 %) was purchased from Thermo Fischer and trimethyladamantylammonium hydroxide (TMAdaOH, 25 %) was purchased from SACHEM Inc.. Deionized (DI) water was produced using an Aqua Solution RODI-C-12A purification system (18.2 MΩ). All reagents were used as received without further purification. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Aluminosilicate forms of zeolites (Al-zeolites) MCM-22, SSZ-13, and ZSM-5 were synthesized following procedures reported in literature [37–39]. The Si/Al molar ratios of Al-zeolite growth mixtures were fixed at 15, 20, and 50, respectively. Gallosilicate isostructures of each zeolite (Ga-zeolites) were synthesized according to the procedures outlined below. The Si/Ga molar ratio of all Ga-zeolite growth mixtures was fixed at 15. 2.3 Synthesis of Ga-MCM-22 The gallosilicate Ga-MCM-22 (MWW framework type) was synthesized under hydrothermal conditions using a growth mixture with a molar composition of 1 SiO2: 0.5 HMI: 4 NaOH: 0.033 Ga2O3: 35 H2O. In a typical synthesis, gallium nitrate (0.257 g, 1.00 mmol) was dissolved in a mixture of 1 M sodium hydroxide (2.422 g, 60.25 mmol) and DI water (9.550 g, 0.530 mol) while stirring at room temperature. The organic structure-directing agent (OSDA) hexamethylenimine (0.748 g, 7.46 mmol) was then added dropwise to the growth solution, which was then allowed to age overnight at room temperature until homogeneous. Next, fumed silica (0.900 g, 14.97 mmol) was added in small portions to ensure maximum dispersion of the silicon source. The resulting gel was introduced into a 60 ml Teflon liner within a stainless-steel acid digestion bomb (Parr Instruments), which was heated at 150 ℃ for 7 days in a Thermo Fisher gravity oven at autogenous pressure and under rotation (60 rpm). The vessel was quenched in water to room temperature. The solids were isolated and washed with DI water by centrifugation (6000 rpm) for 5 min three times before drying at 100 ℃ overnight. As-synthesized Ga-MCM-22 zeolite was calcined in air at 550 ℃ for 8 h to remove occluded OSDA. The calcined material was then converted to proton form (H-form) by refluxing three times in 1.0 M NH4NO3 solution (1.0 g of zeolite per 50 ml of solution) at 80 ℃ for 2 h followed by calcination at 550 ℃ for 5 h in a Thermo Scientific Linderberg Blue M box furnace. 2.4 Synthesis of Ga-SSZ-13 The gallosilicate Ga-SSZ-13 (CHA framework type) was synthesized under hydrothermal conditions using a growth mixture with a molar composition of 1 SiO2: 0.2 TMAdaOH: 0.2 NaOH: 0.033 Ga2O3: 44 H2O. In a typical synthesis, gallium nitrate hydrate (0.6242 g, 2.42 mmol) was dissolved in a mixture of 50 wt% NaOH (0.593 g, 7.41 mmol), 25 wt% TMAdaOH (6.262 g, 7.41 mmol), and DI water (24.254 g, 1.35 mol). Fumed silica (2.222 g, 36.24 mmol) was then added in small portions to ensure maximum dispersion of the silicon source. The growth mixture was aged overnight under continuous stirring at room temperature. The resulting gel was placed in a Teflon-lined stainless-steel acid digestion bomb and heated at 160 °C for 11 days under static condition in an oven. The resulting solids were washed, dried, and calcined to produce H-form Ga-SSZ-13 using the same procedure described above. 2.5 Synthesis of Ga-ZSM-5 The gallosilicate Ga-ZSM-5 (MFI framework type) was synthesized under hydrothermal conditions using a growth mixture with a molar composition of 1 SiO2: 0.15 TPAOH: 0.04 NaOH: 0.033 Ga2O3: 25 H2O. In a typical synthesis, gallium nitrate (0.589 g, 2.30 mmol) was dissolved in a mixture of 50 wt% sodium hydroxide (0.110 g, 1.37 mmol) and DI water (13.73 g, 0.762 mol) while stirring at room temperature. The OSDA tetrapropylammonium hydroxide (2.615 g, 5.14 mmol) and silicon source tetraethyl orthosilicate (7.291 g, 0.034 mol) were added to the growth solution. The solution was allowed to age for 2 h until homogeneous. The resulting gel was introduced into a 60 ml Teflon liner within a stainless-steel acid digestion bomb, which was rotated (60 rpm) at 170 ℃ and autogenous pressure for 2 days in an oven. Sample isolation and conversion to H-form Ga-ZSM-5 were performed using the same procedure described above. 2.6 Catalyst characterization The crystallinity and phase purity of as-synthesized zeolites were assessed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) using a Rigaku diffractometer (Cu Kα radiation). Textural analysis using the BET method was carried out by obtaining N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms on a Micrometrics ASAP 2020 instrument. The distribution of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites in H-form zeolites was characterized by Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy using pyridine as the probe molecule at elevated temperatures. Pyridine adsorption–desorption measurements were conducted on self-supporting zeolite wafers (approx. 20 mg, 1.3 cm diameter), activated under dry N2 at 500 °C for 2 h. Each zeolite wafer was exposed to pyridine-loaded flow of N2 at 200 °C for 2 h inside an in-house built infrared cell equipped with CaF2 windows. Subsequent desorption took place at 300 °C for 2 h, and the FTIR spectra were recorded on a Nicolet 6700 spectrometer. Brønsted and Lewis acid site concentrations were determined from the intensities of the infrared bands (1550 and 1450 cm−1, respectively) using extinction coefficients provided by Emeis [40]. Total acid site concentrations were measured via NH3 temperature programmed desorption (TPD). Pellets of H-form catalysts were pretreated under 30 sccm of argon (Ar) flow at 550 °C for 5 h. Subsequently, NH3 adsorption was conducted at 150 °C under flow of 3 sccm NH3 with 30 sccm of Ar serving as the carrier gas for 30 min. Physiosorbed ammonia was removed by flushing the catalyst bed with Ar for 3 h at 150 °C. Finally, ammonia desorption occurred by ramping the temperature to 700 °C at a rate of 5 °C min−1. The desorbed ammonia was measured using a Cirrus 3 atmospheric gas analyzer equipped with a quadrupole mass spectrometer. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were obtained using a JEOL 2100 instrument operated at 200 kV in bright field. Powders were mixed with ethanol and sonicated for 5 min prior to be being transferred to a lacey carbon Cu grid mesh 200. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was conducted at the Methodist Hospital Research Institute in the Department of Nanomedicine SEM Core using a Nova NanoSEM 230 instrument operated at high vacuum and equipped with a field emission scope providing a high resolution immersion lens. The Nova NanoSEM 230 was also configured with a Bruker SDD-EDS detector for elemental analysis. Powder samples were dispersed in ethanol and sonicated for 5 min prior to being transferred to carbon taped aluminum holders. Samples were also coated with 15 nm of gold to reduce charging effects. Solid-state magic angle spinning (MAS) 71Ga NMR was performed on a JEOL ECA-500 spectrometer at 11.7 T equipped with a 3.2 mm MAS probe. X-ray photoelectric spectroscopy (XPS) was performed using a PHI 5700 instrument equipped with a monochromatic Al Kα X-ray source (1486.6 eV) operated at 350 W. 2.7 Catalytic reactions Single and dual bed reactions were carried out in a stainless-steel fixed bed micro-reactor with an inner diameter of 7 mm under atmospheric pressure. Prior to the catalytic experiment, the Ga- or Al-zeolite catalyst was pre-treated under a continuous stream of N2 (24 sccm) and O2 (6 sccm) at 550 °C for 6 h and then set to the desired reaction parameters. For alcohol dehydration reactions, we used a temperature of 350 °C and a weight-hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 8 h−1 for methanol transformations and 500 °C and WHSV = 19 h−1 for ethanol transformations. For tandem reactions using a dual bed configuration, we used 350 °C and WHSV = 5 h−1 for methanol to hydrocarbons (MTH) reactions and 500 °C and WHSV = 3 h−1 for ethanol to propylene reactions. In a typical experiment, the upstream bed contained 0.2 g of Ga-zeolite catalyst pellets and 0.6 g silica gel (Davisol Grade 636, 36–60 mesh size); and the downstream bed contained 0.3 g of Al-zeolite catalyst pellets and 0.9 g silica gel. The two beds were separated using quartz wool and WHSV values for each bed are specified in the discussion section. HPLC pure liquid alcohol was used as the reactant and Ar (30 sccm) was used as the inert gas for all reactions. The mole fractions of methanol in the feed are as follows: 15.41 % for single bed methanol to DME, 9.86 % for double bed methanol to hydrocarbons, 23.48 % for single bed ethanol to ethylene, and 4.87 % for double bed ethanol to propylene. The reactor effluent was analyzed on-line with an Agilent 7890B gas chromatography (GC) equipped with a DB-1 capillary column (0.25 mm × 60 m) and a flame ionization detector (FID). The space time yield (STY) of propylene in the ethanol to propylene tandem reactions was calculated according to Eq. (1). (1) S T Y = d e s i r e d p r o d u c t q u a n t i t y c a t a l y s t w e i g h t · t i m e m m o l g - 1 h - 1 For the catalyst regeneration study, the feed to the dual bed reactor was switched from argon to nitrogen and oxygen, using the same pre-treatment conditions listed above (i.e., 24 sccm N2, 6 sccm O2, 550 °C). A total of three cycles were performed with 13 h of reaction followed by 6 h of regeneration. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Preparation of zeolite catalysts We prepared a series of gallosilicates (Ga-zeolites) along with their corresponding aluminosilicates (Al-zeolites) with three different crystal structures: CHA (SSZ-13), MFI (ZSM-5), and MWW (MCM-22). The preparation of Ga-ZSM-5 [26] and all Al-zeolites [37–39] were performed using established protocols, whereas the synthesis of Ga-MCM-22 and Ga-SSZ-13 required modifications to reported synthesis protocols (see Methods for details). Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) of all as-synthesized materials revealed fully-crystalline products without observation of zeolite impurities (Fig. S1). Only the Ga-MCM-22 sample contained small peaks in its PXRD pattern that are not observed for Al-MCM-22, suggesting the presence of trace extra-framework gallium oxide based on similar peaks observed for commercial Ga2O3 (in the region 2θ = 35 – 50°). Scanning electron micrographs (Fig. 1 ) reveal the expected morphology of aluminosilicates Al-MCM-22, Al-SSZ-13, and Al-ZSM-5 as being layered, cubic, and coffin-shaped, respectively. For gallosilicate isostructures, the replacement of Al with Ga does not have a significant effect on crystal size (with the exception of SSZ-13), but does shift the morphology from faceted to more spheroidal shapes for Ga-SSZ-13 and Ga-MCM-22. This is most evident in Ga-SSZ-13 and less apparent in Ga-MCM-22 where layers are seemingly smaller and less aggregated. Ga-ZSM-5 revealed an opposite trend in morphology where the formation of more faceted and aggregated crystals was observed. Transmission electron microscopy images of Ga- and Al-zeolites (Fig. S2) confirm the observed shift in morphology when Al is substituted with Ga. Analysis of extracted solids by energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectroscopy before and after synthesis reveal little difference in the Si/M ratio (M = Ga or Al) between the initial (amorphous) gel and final crystalline product (Table 1 ). Textural analysis of as-synthesized zeolite samples (Table 1) using nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms (Fig. S3) provide the total BET surface area, external surface area, and micropore volume (Vmicro). We observe a slight reduction in total surface area when Al is replaced by Ga, suggesting a higher percentage of extra-framework species in Ga-zeolites. Nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms indicate higher N2 uptake and a larger degree of mesoporosity for Ga-ZSM-5 relative to Ga-SSZ-13 and Ga-MCM-22. The acidity of H-form zeolites (Table 1) was extracted using a combination of NH3 temperature-programmed desorption (Fig. S4) and pyridine FTIR (Fig. S5) measurements to quantify the total acidity and relative Brønsted/Lewis acidity, respectively. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was used to characterize gallium speciation in each Ga-zeolite (Fig. 2 ). The Ga 2p XPS spectra were fitted by two peaks corresponding to framework (1118 – 1119 eV) and extra-framework (1119.5 – 1120.5 eV) gallium, respectively [42,43]. The Ga-MCM-22 sample contains the highest quantity (29 %, Fig. 2A) of extra-framework Ga species, consistent with its large reduction in total surface area compared to Al-MCM-22. The quantity of extra-framework Ga species is significantly less for Ga-SSZ-13 (15 %, Fig. 2B) and Ga-ZSM-5 (11 %, Fig. 2B). The presence of extra-framework Ga species likely contributes to the reduced BET surface area of Ga-zeolite catalysts compared to their Al-zeolite counterparts (Table 1); however, the percentage of Lewis acids among Ga- and Al-zeolites is generally the same (with the exception of Ga-MCM-22 that has much higher percentage of Lewis acid sites compared to Al-MCM-22). As previously discussed, it has been established that the acid strength of Ga-zeolites is less than that of Al-zeolites [20]. This is reflected in the NH3-TPD data (Fig. S4) where the peaks for Ga-zeolites are shifted to lower temperatures compared to those of their Al counterparts with the exception of the CHA framework where Ga-SSZ-13 indicates the presence of a higher temperature region (>620 ℃) that is not present in Al-SSZ-13 (Table S2). The total acid site density calculated from NH3-TPD (Table 1) also reveals significant differences between each Ga- and Al-zeolite isostructure due to the varying degree of the Si/M ratio used, with the exception of the MCM-22 materials where there is little to no change in total acid side density (e.g., 491 vs. 485 umol/g for Ga-MCM-22 and Al-MCM-22, respectively) suggesting that both gallium and aluminum may not always occupy a similar number of acid sites at the same Si/M ratio. Moreover, there is only a marginal difference in the relative percentage of Lewis acids between Ga- and Al-zeolites, with the lone exception being Ga-MCM-22 which has 54 % Lewis acidity compared to 15 % for Al-MCM-22. For all samples, pyridine FTIR was used in accordance with previous studies [40] in literature where Brønsted and Lewis acid sites on solid acid catalysts are associated with peaks at 1540 cm−1 and 1450 cm−1, respectively. XPS analysis of Ga speciation is biased to the external surfaces of zeolite catalysts. In order to measure corresponding bulk properties, we used solid state magic angle spinning (MAS) 71Ga NMR for each Ga-zeolite (Fig. 3 A). The 71Ga NMR spectra distinguish sites with either tetrahedral or non-tetrahedral coordination at peaks around 150 and 7 ppm, respectively. In a previous study, [26] we showed that Ga-ZSM-5 contained only tetrahedrally-coordinated sites that corresponded to either framework (Fig. 3B) or extra-framework (Fig. 3F and G) species. The latter are consistent with Ga-zeolites prepared by post-synthesis processes [26]. Evidence of extra-framework Ga sites in close proximity to framework Ga sites (Fig. 3D–G) was not previously observed in the one-pot synthesis of Ga-ZSM-5, but extra-framework Ga3+ species were reported in studies by Bell and coworkers [44]. For the Ga-zeolites prepared in this study, we observe only tetrahedral coordination for Ga-ZSM-5 and Ga-SSZ-13 (Fig. 3A). The percentage of framework and extra-framework species is not easily extracted from NMR data [45–47], thus we cannot differentiate the population of Ga species. For the Ga-MCM-22 sample, we observe non-tetrahedral extra-framework gallium species (Fig. 3C and E) that are indicated by the 7 ppm peak. This is consistent with the small Bragg peaks of gallium oxide observed in the PXRD pattern (Fig. S1), the relatively high percentage of Lewis acidity (Table 1), and the highest fraction of extra-framework species detected in XPS data (Fig. 2A) among the three Ga-zeolite samples. 3.2 Catalytic performance: Methanol to hydrocarbons In the conversion of methanol to hydrocarbons (MTH), there has been extensive research on the key dehydration intermediate, dimethyl ether (DME), responsible for driving the first C – C bond formation and dictating hydrocarbon pool mechanistic pathways [6,9,48]. For this reason, prior reports investigating a combination of methanol (MeOH) and DME feeds (e.g., MeOH, DME, and DME/water) for MTH have shown that DME is signficantly more reactive than methanol, enhances catalyst lifetime, and favors the olefin cycle pathway [49]. Additionally, MTH catalyst deactivation has been linked to the formation of formaldehyde, known to be a coke precursor and a byproduct of methanol oxidation, which is bypassed when using DME as the feed. One limitation for the direct use of DME as the reagent is its high cost relative to that of methanol. Here we explore the use of Ga-zeolites as selective dehydration catalysts for conversion of methanol to DME at conditions comparable to the MTH reaction (i.e., higher temperature than those required for conventional methanol dehydration catalysts). (2) 2 M e O H ↔ D M E + H 2 O As shown in Fig. 4 , Ga-MCM-22 achieves approximately complete methanol conversion and DME selectivity at 350 °C, which is within the upper range of temperatures employed in conventional methanol dehydration and falls within a typical range used for the MTH reaction. We only observe slight Ga-MCM-22 catalyst deactivation within 20 h of reaction time (Fig. 4A) where the methanol conversion decreases to 96 % while DME selectivity remains fixed at 100 % (Fig. 4B). The Ga-SSZ-13 catalyst has an initial conversion of 100 % but rapidly deactivates shortly after exposure to methanol, reaching a steady state conversion of 28 % within 15 h of reaction time. The DME selectivity over the Ga-SSZ-13 catalyst is initially lower (86 %) due to the formation of C3 and C4 products (Fig. S7) over a short period of time on stream (TOS), which putatively induces deactivation in the small-pore zeolite. As the catalyst deactivates, we observe a progressive increase in DME selectivity which reaches 100 % within 5 h reaction time (i.e., shortly after the catalyst begins to deactivate). The Ga-ZSM-5 catalyst exhibits lower activity than Ga-MCM-22, but similar to the latter there is only minimal deactivation over the total time on stream (Fig. 4A). There is, however, a noticeable difference in performance regarding DME selectivity (Fig. 4B), which monotonically increases with reaction time (from 24 to 60 %) owing to the suppression of side products (primarily C3 and C4 species, Fig. S7). We find that Ga-MCM-22 is an exceptional catalyst for methanol dehydration given its high methanol conversion and DME selectivity relative to conventional catalysts over a broad range of reaction temperatures, spanning from 250 °C (Fig. S9) to 350 °C (Fig. 5 ). In Fig. 5 we compare the methanol conversion and DME selectivity of Ga-MCM-22 to catalysts reported in literature (see Table S3 for details of each catalyst and corresponding reaction conditions). The majority of catalysts operate in the range of 200 – 290 °C, while approximately one-third of the catalysts have been tested in the range of 300 – 400 °C. The latter are largely non-zeolitic materials, whereas the majority of reactions involving zeolite catalysts tend to operate below 300 °C, which includes commercial Al-zeolite catalysts MFI, FER, MOR, and *BEA [6]. When conventional Al-zeolite catalysts are used at higher temperatures, their strong Brønsted acidity cannot prevent subsequent reactions of DME by the hydrocarbon pool mechanism. In order to achieve higher methanol conversion without sacrificing DME selectivity, many studies have investigated zeolites (e.g., MFI, FAU, and MOR) where their acid site density is reduced by methods that include functionalization (fluorination, chlorination, silylation), exchanged oxides (MgO, Sb2O3), and exchanged cations/metals (Na, Fe, Co, Ni, Cr, Zr, La, etc.). [21,50,51] Similar approaches have been used for non-zeolitic materials, such as γ-Al2O3 with functionalization (fluorination, chlorination) and doping with oxides (e.g., SiO2, Ti(SO4)2, B2O3, and ZrO2). Others include various mesoporous materials (MCM-41, SBA-15, HMS, MCF, and MSU) with and without dopants (e.g., Al). [52,53] The performance of Ga-MCM-22 (gold star in Fig. 5) is superior to other catalysts, noting that conventional materials are typically evaluated at much longer methanol contact times (e.g., WHSV = 1 to 4 h−1) compared to those in this study (WHSV = 8 h−1). A distinguishing aspect of Ga-zeolites compared to others in Fig. 5 is the methodology by which their acidity is tuned. Notably, here we replace framework Al with a less acidic heteroatom, counter to methods in literature where acid site density is reduced by incorporation of extra-framework species to replace protons (i.e., Brønsted acid sites). Our approch is more complementary to prior studies of zeotypes, such as silicoaluminophosphates (SAPOs) and aluminophosphates (AlPOs), that introduce phosphorus as an alternative heteroatom to tailor acid strength [54–56]. If we compare the performance of Ga-MCM-22 to SAPO and AlPO zeotypes at the same reaction temperature (350 ℃, Fig. 5), it is reported that AlPOs (e.g., AlPO-5, −11, and −41) can achieve approximatley 100 % DME selectivity but cannot match the methanol conversion of Ga-MCM-22. [7] Similarly, SAPOs (SAPO-5, −11, −41) can attain 100 % DME selectivity as methanol dehydration catalysts at lower temperatures but become less effective at 350 ℃ (e.g., with SAPO-11 exhibiting the best performance among all SAPOs with 84 % methanol conversion and 42 % DME selectivity). [7]. Prior studies have shown that DME selectivity is directely correlated with less acidic sites and inversely correlated with strong acid sites [9,57]. The relative roles of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites in methanol dehydration has been considered where it is generally believed that Brønsted acid sites are more responsible for DME formation [57,58]. Functionalization and exchange of Al-zeolite catalysts reduces the number of strong Brønsted acid sites, which achieves higher DME selectivity at the expense of reduced activity, thus requiring longer contact times to achieve higher methanol conversion. The reduced Brønsted acidity of Ga-zeolites allows for high conversion and selectivity at much shorter contact times. The three Ga-zeolites examined in this study also contain a large percentage of Lewis acid sites relative to their Al-zeolite counterparts. It is not well understood what role these species contribute to methanol dehydration; however, it is interesting to note that there are clear differences between the performance of the three Ga-zeolites that suggest there are factors beyond replacing Al with Ga that contribute to the activity of the catalyst. Ga-MCM-22 is a standout among the zeolite frameworks selected for this study. One notable difference of Ga-MCM-22 is the presence of a small quantity of gallium oxide. Davis et al. [59] reported the activity of gallium oxide for the dehydration of numerous alcohols (e.g., propanol and butanol) at low temperature (≤200 ℃) leads to moderate conversions (<50 %). Izzo et al. [60] explored the competing processes of dehydration and dehydrogenation for methanol over a gallium oxide catalyst at higher temperature (400 ℃) and observed low DME selectivity (ca. 35 %) with a range of byproducts (e.g., CO2, CO, CH4, CH2O, H2) that are not observed in our reactions with Ga-zeolites. To assess the potential role of gallium oxide, we tested commercially available Ga2O3 for methanol dehydration at identical reaction conditions to that of the Ga-zeolites and found that the catalyst exhibits low conversion (∼35 %) with 100 % DME selectivity (Fig. S10) over 20 h time on stream. These findings suggest that extra-framework Ga2O3 in Ga-MCM-22 may have a small contribution to the overall catalytic performance, but other Ga sites are needed to achieve both 100 % conversion and 100 % DME selectivity. Another notable observation we have identified is an elemental zoning effect among all three Ga-zeolites favoring Ga in the bulk over the exterior rim. This was identified by comparing bulk Si/Ga ratios extracted from EDX with surface Si/Ga ratios analyzed by XPS (Table S4). Our findings reveal that for Ga-MCM-22, Ga-SSZ-13, and Ga-ZSM-5 the Si/Ga ratios are 1.5 to 3.0 times greater in exterior surfaces compared to the bulk. It remains to be determined what factors differentiate the unique performance of Ga-MCM-22 over those of Ga-SSZ-13 and Ga- ZSM-5. It is likely that there are differences in Ga speciation (and hence acid strength) that cannot be easily discerned by common analytical techniques; or perhaps there are effects associated with crystal structure (i.e., confinement) and/or the distribution of Ga species (i.e., acid siting). The relatively weak acid strength of Ga-zeolites enables existing fixed bed reactors utilizing Al-zeolites at high temperatures to be easily configured as an integrated dual bed system where the Ga-zeolite (placed upstream as bed B1) functions as a pre-treatment catalyst to convert a cheaper feed into one that is a more efficient reactant for the Al-zeolite catalyst (placed downstream as bed B2). This general reactor configuration is illustrated in Scheme 1. Here we compare a series of tandem catalysts using three different Ga-zeolites upstream for methanol dehydration and Al-ZSM-5 downstream for the conversion of DME to hydrocarbons (Fig. 6 A). Plots of methanol/DME conversion versus time on stream reveal the following trends in the deactivation rates of tandem catalysts: Ga-SSZ-13 > Ga-MCM-22 > Ga-ZSM-5. The Ga-MCM-22(B1) – Al-ZSM-5(B2) dual bed exhibits a longer catalyst lifetime than the single bed of Al-ZSM-5 (control) as a result of a 100 % DME selectivity upstream from the methanol dehydration catalyst. The Ga-ZSM-5(B1) – Al-ZSM-5(B2) dual bed results in the longest catalyst lifetime owing to a reduced DME and increased light olefins content of the feed sent to the downstream catalyst. This is reflected in the product selectivity (Fig. 6B) with a higher percentage of C3 and C4 species (i.e., the byproducts of methanol dehydration upstream, Fig. S7); and it is also consistent with the overall yield of propylene, which is highest for the Ga-ZSM-5(B1) – Al-ZSM-5(B2) dual bed configuration. We also assessed a single bed containing a physical mixture of Ga-MCM-22 and Al-ZSM-5 and observed a dramatic reduction in catalyst lifetime compared to both the control and dual bed configurations. Previous studies have reported increased catalyst lifetime when DME is introduced as the reactant instead of methanol [61], which can explain the improved performance of dual bed configurations. Interestingly, when the most efficient dehydration catalyst (Ga-MCM-22) is combined as a physical mixture with Al-ZSM-5 in a single bed, the performance is significantly worse than that of the dual bed configuration. Although the exact mechanism(s) for the trends observed in Fig. 6A is elusive, evidence can be gleaned from differences in product distributions at early time on stream (Fig. 6B). The physical mixture produces the highest aromatics selectivity, which accelerates the rate of coking [10,62]. Moreover, our previous study of Ga/Al-ZSM-5 zeolites [26] demonstrated that Ga species promote aromatization, which can explain why the physical mixture of both Ga- and Al-zeolites increases the rate of catalyst deactivation relative to that of the dual bed configuration. When comparing the latter to the single bed of Al-ZSM-5, the effluent from the dual bed contains less methane, consistent with a reduced rate of catalyst deactivation. We also observe higher C3 and C2 selectivities for the Ga-MCM-22(B1) – Al-ZSM-5(B2) dual bed, which is consistent with the study by Martinez-Espin et al. [49] showing a higher selectivity to light olefins when methanol is replaced with DME as the reactant. A comparison of selectivities (Fig. 6B) reveals the following trend in C3/C2 ratio (from lowest to highest): Ga-MCM-22/Al-ZSM-5 (mixed) < Al-ZSM-5 < Ga-MCM-22(B1) – Al-ZSM-5(B2) < Ga-SSZ-13(B1) – Al-ZSM-5(B2) < Ga-ZSM-5(B1) – Al-ZSM-5(B2). The yield of propylene is highest for the Ga-MCM-22(B1) – Al-ZSM-5(B2) dual bed configuration. In terms of aromatics, the configurations that result in the largest rate of catalyst deactivation, Ga-SSZ-13(B1) – Al-ZSM-5(B2) and Ga-MCM-22/Al-ZSM-5 (mixed), have the lowest and highest aromatics selectivity, respectively. We posit the likely cause for a short lifetime in the former configuration is the low yield of DME from the upstream Ga-SSZ-13 catalyst, and possibly the generation of pre-coking species (carried to the downstream catalyst). For the physical mixture, there is a high percentage of methanol throughout the catalyst bed, which likely contributes to a relatively faster rate of catalyst deactivation in addition to gallium’s promotion of aromatic species (i.e., coke precursors). A consequence of the methanol dehydration reaction in the upstream bed is the formation of water, which is known to decrease the rate of MTH reactions and subsequently form coke deposits leading to increased downstream catalyst deactivation. The presence of water in feeds to the Al-ZSM-5 catalyst (bed B2) would be expected to reduce the efficiency of the tandem reactor design over what could be achieved by using a pure (anhydrous) DME feed; however, the improved performance of the dual-bed Ga-MCM-22/Al-ZSM-5 and Ga-ZSM-5/Al-ZSM-5 configurations over that of a single Al-ZSM-5 bed (Fig. 6A) reveals that the positive effects of converting methanol to DME outweighs the negative impact of water generated from the upstream reaction. This is consistent with prior reports demonstrating the carbon conversion capacity is 8.3-times higher for a DME/water feed compared to a pure methanol feed [39,49,63]. 3.3 Catalytic performance: Ethanol to propylene To explore the broader applicability of Ga-zeolites in alcohol dehydration reactions, we chose to assess the dehydration of a heavier alcohol, ethanol (EtOH), which selectively produces ethylene. The increased steric hindrance associated with EtOH proximal to the active sites in zeolite catalysts is more pronounced than MeOH and may impact the performance of Ga-zeolite dehydration reactions. (3) EtOH ↔ C 2 H 4 + H 2 O Heavier alcohols (i.e. ethanol and propanol) are readily derived from biomass and represent a sustainable feedstock for the synthesis of olefins. Most industrial processes use alumina-based catalysts (e.g., γ-Al2O3) for the ethanol to ethylene reaction whereas zeolites are less studied; however, it has been shown that certain zeolites (e.g., ZSM-5, SAPO-34) exhibit higher activity than conventional ethanol dehydration catalysts [64–66]. Moreover, zeolites can operate at optimal reaction conditions, such as lower temperatures. One of the challenges facing zeolites is catalyst stability owing to their propensity to coke. We hypothesize that Ga-zeolites with reduced acid site strength could increase catalyst lifetime beyond what has been observed for Al-zeolites, while also enabling operation at higher temperatures without sacrificing ethylene selectivity, similar to our findings for methanol dehydration. A typical range of reaction temperature for ethanol dehydration is 300 – 500 ℃. [64] For our studies we selected the uppermost temperature with WHSV = 19 h−1, which is a significantly shorter contact time compared to conventional alumina-based catalysts that typically operate at WHSV = 0.1 – 1.0 h−1. [64] Here we compared the performance of all three Ga-zeolites (Ga-MCM-22, Ga-ZSM-5, and Ga-SSZ-13) in terms of ethanol conversion and ethylene selectivity. The activity of all catalysts is comparable given the observation of 100 % ethanol conversion (Fig. 7 A) over a 20 h reaction time. We see notable differences in product selectivity (Fig. 7B) with Ga-MCM-22 exhibiting 100 % ethylene selectivity. The Ga-SSZ-13 catalyst exhibits 80 % ethylene selectivity, with propylene (15 %) and C4= (5 %) as undesired products. For Ga-ZSM-5 there is a progressive decrease in ethylene selectivity (from 52 to 15 %) over the course of the reaction with a relatively constant propylene selectivity (25 – 30 %), a small amount of ethane (<7%), and a progressive increase in C4= selectivity (from 16 to 61 %). Similar to the approach used for the dual-bed MTH reactor, here we use a similar configuration for the conversion of ethanol to propylene where the upstream catalyst (Ga-zeolite) converts a cheap feedstock (ethanol) to a more value-added intermediate (ethylene) that we posit is more reactive for conversion downstream over the Al-zeolite catalyst to the desired product (propylene). Prior studies have examined ethanol to propylene reactions using CHA-type zeolites [38,67]. Lehmann and Seidel-Morgenstern proposed a mechanism for this reaction where propylene is always generated directly from ethylene rather than ethanol, thus requiring an initial dehydration step [67]. Hunger et al. also reported CHA-type zeolite (Al-SSZ-13) to exhibit the highest adsorption capacity and best activity towards propylene among several other Al-zeolites (e.g., MOR, *BEA, MFI) tested in the ethylene to propylene reaction. [38] As a benchmark, we first assessed a single bed reactor containing Al-SSZ-13 catalyst (Fig. 8 A) and observed a rapid decrease in propylene selectivity. We have opted to report reaction data with respect to ethanol conversion, although it is 100 % in all cases, rather than ethylene conversion due to varying ethylene selectivities observed for upstream Ga-zeolites. The selectivities reported in Fig. 8 reflect the entire system (i.e., both catalyst beds). Within the first 5 h of reaction, there is a monotonic reduction in propylene selectivity (starting from an initial value of 30 %) with a concomitant increase in C4=, the side-product commonly reported for reactions over CHA-type zeolites [38]. When the Ga-MCM-22 catalyst is placed upstream of the Al-SSZ-13 catalyst in a dual bed configuration (Fig. 8B), there is an increase in the initial propylene selectivity (from 30 to 40 %), a reduced rate at which propylene selectivity decreases with time on stream, and a decrease in the amount of C4= side product. We assessed two different dual bed configurations where the downstream catalyst was fixed (Al-SSZ-13) and we replaced the catalyst upstream with Ga-SSZ-13 (Fig. 8C) and Ga-ZSM-5 (Fig. 8D). The Ga-SSZ-13(B1) – Al-SSZ-13(B2) dual bed results in a higher propylene selectivity (initially ca. 70 %) due to the generation of propylene in the upstream reaction over Ga-SSZ-13 (Fig. S11A). This is also reflected in a noticeable increase in propylene space time yield (STY, Fig. 9 ). The Ga-SSZ-13(B1) – Al-SSZ-13(B2) dual bed also produces a small amount of ethane (ca. 10 %) as an additional side product. The Ga-ZSM-5(B1) – Al-SSZ-13(B2) dual bed (Fig. 8D) is the best performing configuration with the highest propylene selectivity (maintained >50 %) and lowest C4= selectivity (<10 %) over the 20 h reaction period. One unique feature of this dual bed configuration is a relatively constant selectivity profile with time on stream compared to the other three dual/single bed configurations. This can be explained in part by the fact that Ga-ZSM-5 produces the highest amount of propylene upstream, which is also reflected in the highest propylene space time yield for the Ga-ZSM-5(B1) – Al-SSZ-13(B2) dual bed (Fig. 9). To evaluate the long-term stability of the best performing dual bed configuration, Ga-ZSM-5(B1) – Al-SSZ-13(B2), we conducted three catalytic cycles of ethanol to propylene under identical conditions with catalyst regeneration between each cycle (Fig. S12). Regeneration of the dual bed involved thermal oxidative treatment at 550 ℃ for 6 h (see Experimental Methods for details). The dual bed configuration demonstrated consistent activity with very little loss in propylene yield over all three catalytic cycles, indicating the active sites in both Ga-ZSM-5 and Al-SSZ-13 remain largely intact and accessible after restoring catalyst activity with each regeneration step. The minor decline in propylene yield underscores the catalytic potential for long-term industrial use where operational consistency is paramount. 3.4 Unique characteristics and advantages of Ga-zeolites The exact nature of active sites in Ga-zeolites remains elusive and is a subject of ongoing investigation. Literature attributes the reactivity of alcohol dehydration catalysts to Brønsted acid sites rather than Lewis acids [57,68,69]; however, the best performing Ga-zeolite (Ga-MCM-22) contains a much higher percentage of Lewis acid sites relative to other Ga-zeolites examined in this study. We confirmed that this performance is not entirely attributed to the presence of small amounts of extra-framework gallium oxide (Fig. S10), but it is less evident what role extra-framework Ga3+ species contribute to dehydration reactions. Our previous study using combined 71Ga MAS NMR and X-ray adsorption spectroscopy (XAS) revealed the challenges of quantifying the fractions of tetrahedral framework and extra-framework Ga species [26]. In the same previous study, we reported density functional theory calculations of Ga,Al-ZSM-5 catalysts for non-oxidative ethylene dehydroaromatization wherein it was observed that the barrier for ethylene activation over Ga Brønsted acid sites is nearly twice that of Al sites. Therefore, it is surprising that C3 and C4 products are formed during ethanol dehydration over some Ga-zeolites (e.g., Ga-SSZ-13 and Ga-ZSM-5) but not for others (e.g., Ga-MCM-22). This seems to suggest there is a unique property of active sites in the Ga-MCM-22 catalyst that extends beyond shape selectivity. One of the advantages of Ga-zeolites over conventional Al-zeolites for alcohol dehydration reactions is the ability to generate the catalyst via a one-pot (single-step) synthesis, thereby avoiding the need to perform post-synthesis functionalization, oxide impregnation, or ion exchange to reduce the acid site density. This enables reactions with Ga-zeolites to be carried out at much higher space velocity (i.e., less alcohol contact time) to achieve higher conversion and selectivity than what has been reported for other Al-zeolites and related materials. In this study, we demonstrated the strategic advantages of using zeolites with reduced acid strength in tandem reactions wherein the Ga-zeolite converts a cheaper reagent into one that is more expensive but also more desirable for downstream processes utilizing Al-zeolites to convert intermediates to light olefins. A potential downside of this dual bed configuration is the generation of water for the intermediate feeds that are directly sent to the downstream bed. This is certainly relevant for methanol to hydrocarbons where water in the feed has been shown to reduce the overall performance of Al-zeolite catalysts; however, to the best of our knowledge, similar studies have not been reported for ethanol to propylene reactions over Al-zeolites. Another potential downside of using dual bed configurations in scaled-up reactors is increased pressure drop. However, for the conditions tested in our studies, both of these effects do not appear to compromise the overall performance of dual bed Ga-/Al-zeolite configurations, which outperform conventional single-bed Al-zeolite counterparts. Indeed, the Ga-MCM-22 catalyst exhibits the highest alcohol conversion and desired product selectivity among any alcohol dehydration catalyst reported in literature. Moreover, we demonstrate that the long lifetime of this catalyst is maintained at higher reaction temperatures, which addresses concerns raised in literature regarding the need to develop more (hydro)thermally-stable zeolite dehydration catalysts [9,66]. In the case of MTH reactions, we also show for the tandem reaction what has already been demonstrated in prior literature, which is that the generation of DME reduces the rate of coking in Al-zeolites, thereby extending catalyst lifetime. 4 Conclusions In summary, we have shown that gallosilicate zeolites are superior alcohol dehydration catalysts relative to their aluminosilicate counterparts, with Ga-MCM-22 outperforming all conventional dehydration catalysts reported in literature. In the methanol to DME reaction, Ga-MCM-22 exhibits nearly 100 % methanol conversion and DME selectivity with a very slow rate of deactivation. The fact that Ga-SSZ-13 and Ga-ZSM-5 catalysts are less active and selective than Ga-MCM-22 suggests there are differences in the intrinsic strength (and possibly speciation) of Ga acid sites as a function of zeolite crystal structure. Differences in activity among the three Ga-zeolites is less evident in the ethanol dehydration reaction, but significant differences in product selectivity align with the results of methanol dehydration pointing to variable properties of Ga sites in gallosilicate zeolites. There is debate in literature surrounding differences in the intrinsic acidity of Al-zeolites and whether Brønsted acid strength is influenced by Al siting and framework topolopy [70–74]. Our findings for Ga-zeolites are seemingly more consistent with studies of Al-zeolites that claim differences in Al acid site strength. For example, Hibbitts and Gounder have shown that acid siting (e.g., paired Al sites) can impact the kinetics of methanol dehydration [75]. There are relatively few instances when the replacement of Al Brønsted acids with less-acidic heteroatoms produces a more optimal zeolite catalyst. The most common example is dehydrogenation catalysts where gallium and boron have proven to be more effective than aluminum [15,17,76,77]; however, the reactive species in these materials is largely attributed to extra-framework species. In general, zeolites with reduced acidity tend to be suboptimal catalysts for a majority of hydrocarbon processing reactions (e.g., cracking, MTH, oligomerization, etc.). Here we show that Ga-zeolites are effective dehydration catalysts and can, therefore, be used in tandem with more acidic zeolites to enhance the production of light olefins. Although more in-depth studies are required to fully elucidate the fundamental mechanisms of these reactions and the nature of the active site(s), we posit that Ga-zeolites could be used for the dehydration of other alcohols (i.e., beyond methanol and ethanol). To this end, we believe that the approach demonstrated in this study offers a guideline for engineering heteroatom zeolite isostructures with tailored acidity for a broader range of tandem reactions. coredata.dc:description: Zeolites are versatile catalysts owing to their tunable acidity where the active site(s) can be placed within the crystal framework or as extra-framework species in confined pores. A common approach to tailor Brønsted acidity is heteroatom exchange involving the replacement of framework aluminum with alternative elements. Introduction of heteroatoms often results in less acidic catalysts that can be used in tandem reactions for targeted reactive intermediates. In this study, we prepare a series of three different zeolites with MWW, CHA, and MFI frameworks as aluminosilicates and gallosilicates to demonstrate their performance in alcohol dehydration reactions. The two reactions examined in this study are methanol conversion to dimethyl ether and ethanol conversion to ethylene. Our findings reveal that Ga-zeolites exhibit superior performance with Ga-MCM-22 (MWW) achieving nearly 100 % alcohol conversion and selectivity to desired products at contact times that are significantly less than most dehydration catalysts reported in literature. The unique properties of Ga-zeolites are attributed to their reduced acid site strength via a direct (one-pot) synthesis that avoids conventional time-intensive, multi-step post-synthesis modifications of Al-zeolites. Here we demonstrate the use of Ga-zeolites as tandem catalysts when paired with a downstream Al-zeolite in a dual-bed reactor configuration to convert cheaper reagents (alcohols) upstream to more desired intermediates as feeds for downstream catalysts to produce light olefins. We demonstrate that dual beds using Ga-zeolite – Al-ZSM-5 (upstream–downstream) pairings outperform single bed configurations with Al-ZSM-5 or a physical mixture (Ga-/Al-zeolite) for methanol to hydrocarbons reactions, with notable improvements in catalyst lifetime and increased light olefins selectivity. Similarly, dual beds using Ga-zeolite – Al-SSZ-13 (upstream–downstream) pairings result in improved performance for ethanol to propylene reactions with significant increases in propylene selectivity (>20 %) compared to a conventional single bed configuration of Al-SSZ-13. Overall, this study offers a new perspective on the use of heteroatom-exchanged zeolite catalysts in tandem reactions as a means of capitalizing on their reduced acid site strength and suggests differences in the intrinsic acidity of zeolite crystal structures.
coredata.dc:title: Pairing Ga/Al-Zeolites with tailored acidity as tandem catalysts for the conversion of alcohols to olefins
